newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Coconut Oil - Prices seen steady on tight supply.
newsitem.headline: Coconut Oil - Prices seen steady on tight supply.

text.p: Coconut oil prices are expected to stay steady to higher in a generally quiet market this week as some mills in the Philippines have temporarily shut down ahead of the Christmas holidays, vegetable oil traders said.
"I don't see any activity in the last two weeks of the year with most mills closing early to accumulate enough copra for next year's orders," said one local trader.
"Those who were not covered for the rest of the year may either get it (coconut oil) at current high prices, or pay a little premium, due to meagre supply in Rotterdam," said another trader.

Coconut oil sellers quoted between $830 to $835 per tonne CIF for November/December shipment on Friday from $820 per tonne on December 9, the trade group United Coconut Associations of the Philippines Inc (UCAP) said.
They asked $780 per tonne CIF for January/February shipments on Friday from $770 to $775 per tonne on December 9, UCAP said.
Philippine traders pegged coconut oil stocks in Rotterdam at 27,000 tonnes as of end of last week from the previous 34,000 tonnes.
Coconut oil requirement in Rotterdam was placed by Philippine vegetable oil traders at 55,000 tonnes a month.
Traders said they only expect one ship, Stolt Sapphire, with a meagre cargo of 3,000 tonnes, to arrive in Rotterdam on December 21.
"Despite prospects of new arrivals in Europe, prices have been holding in the past few days indicating that the cargo of Stolt Sapphire may have been taken up," said another trader.
Philippine coconut oil exports from December 1 to 12 reached 65,000 tonnes from 111,466 for the whole month of December 1995, UCAP said.

The state-agency Philippine Coconut Authority said final data indicated coconut oil exports from January to September this year dropped to 590,381 tonnes from 1,050,314 tonnes in the same period last year.
Traders attributed the steep drop in Philippine coconut oil exports to a series of typhoons which ravaged coconut plantations in late 1995.
Philippine coconut oil output is expected to recover in the second quarter of 1997, they said.
